ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge about the connections between music and literature of the African diaspora!
Analyzing literature with themes of diaspora, sound, and identity.
learned more about the african diaspora--its intersectionality and ever-present nature. i also learned how to be cognizant of sound throughout my everyday life
College writing, Analytic skills, Broad and creative thinking, Afro-Diasporic line of thought, Open-mindedness
I gained a lot of insight on topics such as African migration, diasporic identity, and many other concepts.
I learned so much about the African diaspora, analyzing texts, and how to write a well-written essay.

Through this course, I've developed knowledge of various musical, literary, and theatric traditions across the African diaspora, and the ways that cultures of the diaspora have been formed. I've also developed skills in writing research papers and literary analysis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Incredibly strong, no suggestions on how to improve

Strengths: the professor is extremely knowledgeable, supportive, and open to different opinions and interpretations. The readings offer a diverse yet cohesive collection of perspectives that tie together very well.
Weaknesses: we sometimes got off track in terms of assignment deadlines.

Only strengths. Rasheed facilitated such a wonderful environment for learning, was flexible to student needs, and was just so pleasant. it was so nice to 
listen to a piece of African diasporic music in class that students brought in because it allowed us to learn more about the breadth of the diaspora and the people in our class
I loved the course I think the course content was broad and covered various aspects of the African diaspora. There is very little I would change if this course is taught again.

There were no weaknesses, strengths were that the books we read were very interesting and connected very well to other books we read and concepts we discussed in class. I appreciated Professor Rasheed's ability to facilitate class discussions.
The course was an amazing experience- no weaknesses. The course was well-structured and the work was manageable.

The course was incredibly interesting and used a variety of medias to teach, we listened to a large deal of music from artists across the diaspora in addition to reading novels, plays, and watching a film. Our class discussions were always engaging and passionate, and Rasheed fostered an incredible environment for collaboration and discussion in the course. The course was also very helpful in developing writing skills using a variety of assignments, with Rasheed providing detailed, insightful feedback and many opportunities to receive 1-on-1 feedback and workshopping.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! Such rich discussion, texts, music + incredible professor

Absolutely! I think everyone should take a course with Rasheed while they are at Yale, especially if they are interested in reading and writing about race and identity. My writing has improved so much after taking this course, and I've been able to explore some very cool topics I wouldn't have in other classes.
absolutely, 100000%

I would recommend this to any student. I think the course really opened my mind to links I had never considered before and to information that is mostly inaccessible/goes unspoken outside of academic spaces.

I would definitely recommend this course for all students because it widens your perspective on what we know as the Diaspora. The material was very engaging and interesting and the course was a safe space for all.
Yes - especially with Rasheed - the course was very enlightening and the reading materials were very interesting. He provided excellent feedback and made class something to look forward to.

I would strongly recommend this course to another student. It greatly expanded my understanding of the African diaspora and exposed me to many incredible songs and written texts. Rasheed is an incredible professor who creates an engaging and comfortable class environment, and this course has been one of my favorite courses that I've taken at Yale.
